"Help:Pronunciation respelling key"); [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic
language"): عمان‎ __ʻumān__ [[ʕʊˈmaːn]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Arabic
"Help:IPA/Arabic")), officially the **[Sultanate](/wiki/Sultan "Sultan") of
Oman** ([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): سلطنة عُمان‎
__Salṭanat ʻUmān__), is an [Arab](/wiki/Arabs "Arabs") country on the
southeastern coast of the [Arabian Peninsula](/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula "Arabian
Peninsula") in [Western Asia](/wiki/Western_Asia "Western Asia"). Its official
religion is [Islam](/wiki/Islam_in_Oman "Islam in Oman").

Holding a strategically important position at the mouth of the [Persian
Gulf](/wiki/Persian_Gulf "Persian Gulf"), the country shares land borders with
the [United Arab Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates "United Arab Emirates")
to the northwest, [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi Arabia") to the
west, and [Yemen](/wiki/Yemen "Yemen") to the southwest, and shares [marine
borders](/wiki/Maritime_boundary "Maritime boundary") with [Iran](/wiki/Iran
"Iran") and [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"). The coast is formed by the
[Arabian Sea](/wiki/Arabian_Sea "Arabian Sea") on the southeast and the [Gulf
of Oman](/wiki/Gulf_of_Oman "Gulf of Oman") on the northeast. The
[Madha](/wiki/Madha "Madha") and [Musandam](/wiki/Musandam_Governorate
"Musandam Governorate") exclaves are surrounded by the UAE on their land
borders, with the [Strait of Hormuz](/wiki/Strait_of_Hormuz "Strait of
Hormuz") (which it shares with [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran")) and Gulf of Oman
forming Musandam's coastal boundaries.

From the late 17th century, the Omani Sultanate was a [powerful
empire](/wiki/Colonial_empire "Colonial empire"), vying with
[Portugal](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal") and Britain for influence in the
[Persian Gulf](/wiki/Persian_Gulf "Persian Gulf") and [Indian
Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean"). At its peak in the 19th century,
Omani influence or control extended across the Strait of Hormuz to modern-day
[Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran") and [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"), and as
far south as [Zanzibar](/wiki/Zanzibar "Zanzibar").[7] As its power declined
in the 20th century, the sultanate came under the influence of the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Historically, [Muscat](/wiki/Muscat,_Oman "Muscat, Oman") was the principal
trading port of the Persian Gulf region. Muscat was also among the most
important trading ports of the [Indian Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian
Ocean").

The Sultan [Qaboos bin Said al Said](/wiki/Qaboos_bin_Said_al_Said "Qaboos bin
Said al Said") has been the hereditary leader of the country, an [absolute
monarchy](/wiki/Absolute_monarchy "Absolute monarchy"),[8] since 1970.[8]
Sultan Qaboos is the [longest-serving current
ruler](/wiki/Current_reigning_monarchs_by_length_of_reign "Current reigning
monarchs by length of reign") in the Middle East,[9] and third-[longest
current reigning monarch](/wiki/Current_reigning_monarchs_by_length_of_reign
"Current reigning monarchs by length of reign") in the world.

Oman is a member of the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United
Nations"), the [Arab League](/wiki/Arab_League "Arab League"), the [Gulf
Cooperation Council](/wiki/Gulf_Cooperation_Council "Gulf Cooperation
Council"), the [Non-Aligned Movement](/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement "Non-Aligned
Movement") and the [Organisation of Islamic
Cooperation](/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation "Organisation of
Islamic Cooperation"). It has modest oil reserves, ranking [25th
globally](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves "List of countries by
proven oil reserves").[10][11] Nevertheless, in 2010 the [UNDP](/wiki/UNDP
"UNDP") ranked Oman as the most improved nation in the world in terms of
development during the preceding 40 years.[12] A significant portion of its
economy involves [tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_Oman "Tourism in Oman") and trade
of fish, dates, and certain agricultural produce. This sets it apart from its
neighbors' largely oil-dependent economies. Oman is categorized as a [high-
income economy](/wiki/High-income_economy "High-income economy") and ranks as
the 70th most peaceful country in the world according to the [Global Peace
Index](/wiki/Global_Peace_Index "Global Peace Index").[13]

## History

Main article: [History of Oman](/wiki/History_of_Oman "History of Oman")

### Prehistory and ancient history

At Aybut Al Auwal, in the [Dhofar Governorate](/wiki/Dhofar_Governorate
"Dhofar Governorate") of Oman, a site was discovered in 2011 containing more
than 100 surface scatters of stone tools, belonging to a regionally specific
African [lithic industry](/wiki/Lithic_industry "Lithic industry")—the late
[Nubian](/wiki/Nubia "Nubia") Complex—known previously only from the northeast
and [Horn of Africa](/wiki/Horn_of_Africa "Horn of Africa"). Two optically
stimulated luminescence age estimates place the Arabian Nubian Complex at
106,000 years old. This supports the proposition that early human populations
moved from Africa into Arabia during the [Late
Pleistocene](/wiki/Late_Pleistocene "Late Pleistocene").[14]

In recent years known primarily from survey finds, Palaeolithic and Neolithic
sites have come to light most on the eastern coast. Main Palaeolithic sites
include Saiwan-Ghunaim in the Barr al-Hikman.[15] Archaeological remains are
particularly numerous for the Bronze Age [Umm an-Nar](/wiki/Umm_an-Nar "Umm
an-Nar") and [Wadi Suq](/w/index.php?title=Wadi_Suq&action=edit&redlink=1
"Wadi Suq \(page does not exist\)") periods. Sites such as [Baat](/wiki/Baat
"Baat") show accomplished wheel-turned pottery, excellent hand-made stone
vessels, a metals industry, and monumental architecture .[16] The Early
(1300‒300 BC) and Late Iron Ages (100 BC‒300 AD) show more differences than
similarities to each other. Thereafter until the coming of the Ibadhidya
little or nothing of is known.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/World_Heritage_Grave_Al_Ayn_Oman.JPG/220px-
World_Heritage_Grave_Al_Ayn_Oman.JPG)](/wiki/File:World_Heritage_Grave_Al_Ayn_Oman.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:World_Heritage_Grave_Al_Ayn_Oman.JPG "Enlarge")

A grave at [Al Ayn](/wiki/Archaeological_Sites_of_Bat,_Al-Khutm_and_Al-Ayn
"Archaeological Sites of Bat, Al-Khutm and Al-Ayn"), Oman, a World Heritage
site

[Sumerian](/wiki/Sumerian_language "Sumerian language") tablets refer to a
country called Magan[17][18] and [Akkadian](/wiki/Akkadian_language "Akkadian
language") ones Makan,[19][20] a name which links Oman's ancient copper
resources.[21] Mazoon, a Persian name used for the region. Over centuries
tribes from the west settled in Oman, making a living by fishing, farming,
herding or stock breeding, and many present day Omani families trace their
ancestral roots to other parts of Arabia. When the emigrants from northern-
western and south-western Arabia arrived in Oman, they had to compete with the
indigenous population for the best arable land.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Lia_sites.JPG/220px-
Lia_sites.JPG)](/wiki/File:Lia_sites.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Lia_sites.JPG "Enlarge")

Oman, Late Iron Age sites

In the 1970s and 1980s scholars like [John C.
Wilkinson](/w/index.php?title=John_C._Wilkinson&action=edit&redlink=1 "John C.
Wilkinson \(page does not exist\)")[22] believed by virtue of oral history
that in the 6th century BC, the Achaemenids exerted control over the Omani
peninsula, most likely ruling from a coastal center such as
[Suhar](/wiki/Suhar "Suhar").[23] Central Oman has its own indigenous Samad
Late Iron Age cultural assemblage named eponymously from [Samad al-
Shan](/wiki/Samad_al-Shan "Samad al-Shan"). In the northern part of the Oman
Peninsula the [Recent Pre-Islamic Period](/w/index.php?title=Recent_Pre-
Islamic_Period&action=edit&redlink=1 "Recent Pre-Islamic Period \(page does
not exist\)") begins in the 3rd century BCE and extends into the 3rd century
CE. Whether or not Persians brought south-eastern Arabian under their control
is a moot point, since the lack of Persian finds speak against this belief.
Four centuries later, Omanis came in contact with and accepted
[Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam").[24][25] The conversion of Oman is usually
ascribed to [Amr ibn al-As](/wiki/Amr_ibn_al-As "Amr ibn al-As"), who was sent
by the prophet [Muhammad](/wiki/Muhammad "Muhammad") during the [Expedition of
Zaid ibn Haritha (Hisma)](/wiki/Expedition_of_Zaid_ibn_Haritha_\(Hisma\)
"Expedition of Zaid ibn Haritha \(Hisma\)").

### Portuguese colonization

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Seydi_Ali-
Ambush.png/220px-Seydi_Ali-Ambush.png)](/wiki/File:Seydi_Ali-Ambush.png)

[](/wiki/File:Seydi_Ali-Ambush.png "Enlarge")

Seydi Ali Reis and his galleys taken in an ambush by Portuguese forces while
trying to bring back his flotilla from Basra to Suez in August 1554

A decade after [Vasco da Gama](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama "Vasco da Gama")'s
successful voyage around the [Cape of Good Hope](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope "Cape
of Good Hope") and to [India](/wiki/India "India") in 1497–98, the Portuguese
arrived in Oman and occupied [Muscat](/wiki/Muscat,_Oman "Muscat, Oman") for a
143-year period, from 1507 to 1650. Their fortress still remains. In need of
an outpost to protect their sea lanes, the Portuguese built up and fortified
the city, where remnants of their colonial architectural style still exist. An
[Ottoman fleet](/wiki/Ottoman_Navy "Ottoman Navy") [captured Muscat in
1552](/wiki/Capture_of_Muscat_\(1552\) "Capture of Muscat \(1552\)"), during
the fight for control of the Persian Gulf and the Indian Ocean.[26]

The [Ottoman Turks](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") captured Muscat
from the Portuguese in 1581 and held it until 1588. Rebellious tribes
eventually drove out the Portuguese, but were themselves pushed out about a
century later, in 1741, by the leader of an Omani tribe, who began the current
line of ruling sultans. Except for a brief Persian invasion in the late 1740s,
Oman has been self-governing ever since.[27]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Maskat_%26_Oman_map.png/170px-
Maskat_%26_Oman_map.png)](/wiki/File:Maskat_%26_Oman_map.png)

### 18th and 19th centuries

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Sultan%27s_Palace%2C_Zanzibar.JPG/300px-
Sultan%27s_Palace%2C_Zanzibar.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sultan%27s_Palace,_Zanzibar.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Sultan%27s_Palace,_Zanzibar.JPG "Enlarge")

The [Sultan's Palace](/wiki/Palace_Museum,_Zanzibar "Palace Museum, Zanzibar")
in [Zanzibar](/wiki/Zanzibar "Zanzibar"), which was once Oman's capital and
residence of its Sultans

In the 1690s, [Saif bin Sultan](/wiki/Saif_bin_Sultan "Saif bin Sultan"), the
[Imam](/wiki/Imam "Imam") of Oman, pressed down the [Swahili
Coast](/wiki/Swahili_Coast "Swahili Coast"). A major obstacle to his progress
was [Fort Jesus](/wiki/Fort_Jesus "Fort Jesus"), housing the garrison of a
[Portuguese](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal") settlement at [Mombasa](/wiki/Mombasa
"Mombasa"). After a two-year siege, the fort fell to bin Sultan in 1698.
Thereafter the Omanis easily ejected the Portuguese from
[Zanzibar](/wiki/Zanzibar "Zanzibar") and from all other coastal regions north
of [Mozambique](/wiki/Mozambique "Mozambique"). The Persians invaded Oman in
1737. They were driven out in 1749 when the [Al Said](/wiki/Al_Said "Al Said")
dynasty came to power. It continues to rule Oman to this day.

Zanzibar was a valuable property as the main [slave
market](/wiki/Arab_slave_trade#Geography_of_the_slave_trade "Arab slave
trade") of the Swahili Coast, and became an increasingly important part of the
Omani empire, a fact reflected by the decision of the 19th century Imam of
Muscat, [Sa'id ibn Sultan](/wiki/Sa%27id_ibn_Sultan "Sa'id ibn Sultan"), to
make it his main place of residence in 1837. Sa'id built impressive palaces
and gardens in Zanzibar. Rivalry between his two sons was resolved, with the
help of forceful British diplomacy, when one of them,
[Majid](/wiki/Majid_bin_Said_of_Zanzibar "Majid bin Said of Zanzibar"),
succeeded to Zanzibar and to the many regions claimed by the family on the
Swahili Coast. The other son,
[Thuwaini](/wiki/Thuwaini_bin_Said,_Sultan_of_Muscat_and_Oman "Thuwaini bin
Said, Sultan of Muscat and Oman"), inherited [Muscat and
Oman](/wiki/Muscat_and_Oman "Muscat and Oman"). Zanzibar influences in the
[Comoros](/wiki/Comoros "Comoros") archipelago in the Indian Ocean indirectly
introduced Omani customs to the Comorian culture. These influences include
clothing traditions and wedding ceremonies.[28]

In 1783, Oman's Seyyid Sultan, defeated ruler of Muscat, was granted
sovereignty over [Gwadar](/wiki/Gwadar "Gwadar"). This coastal city is located
in the [Makran](/wiki/Makran "Makran") region of what is now the far
southwestern corner of [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"), near the
present-day border of [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran"), at the mouth of the [Gulf of
Oman](/wiki/Gulf_of_Oman "Gulf of Oman").[note 1][29] After regaining control
of Muscat, this sovereignty was continued via an appointed _[wali](/wiki/Wali
"Wali")_ ("governor").

The [Al Hajar Mountains](/wiki/Al_Hajar_Mountains "Al Hajar Mountains"), of
which the [Jebel Akhdar](/wiki/Jebel_Akhdar_\(Oman\) "Jebel Akhdar \(Oman\)")
is a part, separate the country into two distinct regions: the interior, known
as Oman, and the coastal area dominated by the capital, Muscat.[30] In 1913,
control of the country split. The interior was ruled by [Ibadite](/wiki/Ibadi
"Ibadi") imams and the coastal areas by the sultan. Under the terms of the
British-brokered [Treaty of Seeb](/wiki/Treaty_of_Seeb "Treaty of Seeb") of
1920, the sultan recognised the autonomy of the interior. The Sultan of Muscat
would be responsible for the external affairs of Oman.[31]

### Reign of Sultan Said (1932–1970)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/11/Said_Bin_Taimur.jpg/150px-
Said_Bin_Taimur.jpg)](/wiki/File:Said_Bin_Taimur.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Said_Bin_Taimur.jpg "Enlarge")

Sultan Said Bin Taimur

The rule of Sultan [Said bin Taimur](/wiki/Said_bin_Taimur "Said bin Taimur")
was characterised by a [feudal](/wiki/Feudal "Feudal") and isolationist
approach. Imam [Ghalib Alhinai](/wiki/Ghalib_Alhinai "Ghalib Alhinai") was the
elected Imam of the [Imamate of Oman](/wiki/Imamate_of_Oman "Imamate of Oman")
in May 1954.[32] Relations between the Sultan of Muscat, Said bin Taimur, and
Imam Ghalib Alhinai were ruptured over a dispute concerning the right to grant
oil concessions. A subsidiary of the [Iraq Petroleum
Company](/wiki/Iraq_Petroleum_Company "Iraq Petroleum Company") was intensely
interested in some promising geological formations near [Fahud](/wiki/Fahud
"Fahud"). Under the terms of the 1920 treaty of Seeb, the Sultan claimed all
dealings with the oil company as his prerogative. The Imam, on the other hand,
claimed that since the oil was in his territory, anything dealing with it was
an internal matter.[30]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Bahla_Fort-109699.jpg/220px-
Bahla_Fort-109699.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bahla_Fort-109699.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bahla_Fort-109699.jpg "Enlarge")

Bahla Fort

In December 1955, Sultan Said bin Taimur sent troops of the Muscat and Oman
Field Force to occupy the main centres in Oman, including [Nizwa](/wiki/Nizwa
"Nizwa"), the capital of the Imamate of Oman, and [Ibri](/wiki/Ibri
"Ibri").[31] Imam Ghalib Alhinai and his younger brother, [Talib bin Ali
Alhinai](/w/index.php?title=Talib_bin_Ali_Alhinai&action=edit&redlink=1 "Talib
bin Ali Alhinai \(page does not exist\)"), led the Imamate of Oman in the
[Jebel Akhdar War](/wiki/Jebel_Akhdar_War "Jebel Akhdar War") against Sultan
Said bin Taimur's attack on his lands. In July 1957, the Sultan's forces were
withdrawing, but they were repeatedly ambushed, sustaining heavy
casualties.[31] Sultan Said bin Taimur, however, with the intervention of
infantry (two companies of the
[Cameronians](/wiki/Cameronians_\(Scottish_Rifles\) "Cameronians \(Scottish
Rifles\)")), armoured car detachments from the British Army and
[RAF](/wiki/RAF "RAF") aircraft, was able to suppress the rebellion.[33]
Talib's forces retreated to the inaccessible [Jebel
Akhdar](/wiki/Jebel_Akhdar_\(Oman\) "Jebel Akhdar \(Oman\)").[33]

Colonel [David Smiley](/wiki/David_Smiley "David Smiley"), who had been
seconded to organize the Sultan's Armed Forces, managed to isolate the
mountain in autumn 1958 and found a route to the plateau from Wadi Bani
Kharus.[34] On 27 January 1959, they occupied the mountain in a surprise
operation.[34] Ghalib, Talib and Sulaiman managed to escape to [Saudi
Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi Arabia"), where the Imamate's cause was
promoted until the 1970s.[34] Imam Ghalib delegated his brother, [Talib
Alhinai](/w/index.php?title=Talib_Alhinai&action=edit&redlink=1 "Talib Alhinai
\(page does not exist\)"), to present the issue to the [Arab
League](/wiki/Arab_League "Arab League") and the [United
Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") in order to seek recognition
of the Imamate of Oman by peaceful means.[35]

In 1955, the [exclave](/wiki/Exclave "Exclave") coastal [Makran](/wiki/Makran
"Makran") strip acceded to [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") and was made
a district of its [Balochistan province](/wiki/Balochistan_\(Pakistan\)
"Balochistan \(Pakistan\)"), while [Gwadar](/wiki/Gwadar "Gwadar") was not
included in Makran then. On 8 September 1958, Pakistan purchased the Gwadar
enclave from Oman for [US$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States
dollar")3 million.[note 2][36] Gwadar then became a [tehsil](/wiki/Tehsil
"Tehsil") in the Makran district.

Oil reserves were discovered in 1964 and extraction began in 1967. In the
[Dhofar Rebellion](/wiki/Dhofar_Rebellion "Dhofar Rebellion"), which began in
1965, leftist forces were pitted against government troops. As the rebellion
threatened to overthrow the Sultan's rule in [Dhofar](/wiki/Dhofar "Dhofar"),
Sultan Said bin Taimur was deposed in a [bloodless coup
(1970)](/wiki/1970_Omani_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "1970 Omani coup d'état") by his
son [Qaboos bin Said](/wiki/Qaboos_bin_Said "Qaboos bin Said"), who expanded
the [Sultan of Oman's Armed Forces](/wiki/Sultan_of_Oman%27s_Armed_Forces
"Sultan of Oman's Armed Forces"), modernised the state's administration and
introduced social reforms. The uprising was finally put down in 1975 with the
help of forces from [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran"), [Jordan](/wiki/Jordan
"Jordan"), [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") and the British [Royal Air
Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force"), army and [Special Air
Service](/wiki/Special_Air_Service "Special Air Service").

### Reign of Sultan Qaboos (from 1970)

After deposing his father in 1970, [Sultan Qaboos](/wiki/Sultan_Qaboos "Sultan
Qaboos") opened up the country, embarked on economic reforms, and followed a
policy of modernisation marked by increased spending on health, education and
welfare.[37] [Slavery](/wiki/Arab_slave_trade "Arab slave trade"), once a
cornerstone of the country's trade and development, was outlawed in 1970 as
well.[28]

In 1981 Oman became a founding member of the six-nation [Gulf Cooperation
Council](/wiki/Gulf_Cooperation_Council "Gulf Cooperation Council"). Political
reforms were eventually introduced. Historically, voters had been chosen from
among tribal leaders, intellectuals, and businessmen. In 1997 Sultan Qaboos
decreed that women could vote for, and stand for election to, the Majlis al-
Shura, the [Consultative Assembly of Oman](/wiki/Consultative_Assembly_of_Oman
"Consultative Assembly of Oman"). Two women were duly elected to the body.

In 2002, voting rights were extended to all citizens over the age of 21, and
the first elections to the Consultative Assembly under the new rules were held
in 2003. In 2004, the Sultan appointed Oman's first female minister with
portfolio, [Sheikha Aisha bint Khalfan bin Jameel al-
Sayabiyah](/wiki/Aisha_bint_Khalfan_bin_Jameel "Aisha bint Khalfan bin
Jameel"). She was appointed to the post of National Authority for Industrial
Craftsmanship, an office that attempts to preserve and promote Oman's
traditional crafts and stimulate industry.[38] Despite these changes, there
was little change to the actual political makeup of the government. The Sultan
continued to rule by decree. Nearly 100 suspected Islamists were arrested in
2005 and 31 people were convicted of trying to overthrow the government. They
were ultimately pardoned in June of the same year.[10]

Inspired by the [Arab Spring](/wiki/Arab_Spring "Arab Spring") uprisings
taking place throughout the region, [protests](/wiki/2011_Omani_protests "2011
Omani protests") also occurred in Oman during the early months of 2011.
Although they did not call for the ousting of the regime, demonstrators
demanded political reforms, improved living conditions, and the creation of
more jobs. They were dispersed by riot police in February 2011. Sultan Qaboos
reacted by promising jobs and benefits. In October 2011, elections were held
to the Consultative Assembly, to which Sultan Qaboos promised greater powers.
The following year, the government began a crackdown on internet criticism. In
September 2012, trials began of 'activists' accused of posting "abusive and
provocative" criticism of the government online. Six were given jail terms of
12–18 months and fines of around $2,500 each.[39]

## Geography

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/SurOman.jpg/220px-
SurOman.jpg)](/wiki/File:SurOman.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:SurOman.jpg "Enlarge")

The coast of [Sur, Oman](/wiki/Sur,_Oman "Sur, Oman")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Wadi_Shab_%286%29.jpg/120px-
Wadi_Shab_%286%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wadi_Shab_\(6\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wadi_Shab_\(6\).jpg "Enlarge")

Wadi Shab

Oman lies between latitudes [16°](/wiki/16th_parallel_north "16th parallel
north") and [28° N](/wiki/28th_parallel_north "28th parallel north"), and
longitudes [52°](/wiki/52nd_meridian_east "52nd meridian east") and [60°
E](/wiki/60th_meridian_east "60th meridian east"). A vast gravel desert plain
covers most of central Oman, with mountain ranges along the north ([Al Hajar
Mountains](/wiki/Al_Hajar_Mountains "Al Hajar Mountains")) and southeast coast
([Qara or Dhofar
Mountains](/w/index.php?title=Dhofar_Mountains&action=edit&redlink=1 "Dhofar
Mountains \(page does not exist\)")),[40][41] where the country's main cities
are also located: the capital city [Muscat](/wiki/Muscat,_Oman "Muscat,
Oman"), [Sohar](/wiki/Sohar "Sohar") and [Sur](/wiki/Sur,_Oman "Sur, Oman") in
the north, and [Salalah](/wiki/Salalah "Salalah") in the south. Oman's climate
is hot and dry in the interior and humid along the coast. During past epochs,
Oman was covered by ocean, witnessed by the large numbers of fossilized shells
existing in areas of the desert away from the modern coastline.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Oman-Oasis.jpg/220px-
Oman-Oasis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Oman-Oasis.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Oman-Oasis.jpg "Enlarge")

An Omani desert landscape

The peninsula of [Musandam](/wiki/Musandam_Peninsula "Musandam Peninsula")
(Musandem) [exclave](/wiki/Exclave "Exclave"), which has a strategic location
on the [Strait of Hormuz](/wiki/Strait_of_Hormuz "Strait of Hormuz"), is
separated from the rest of Oman by the [United Arab
Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates "United Arab Emirates").[42] The series
of small towns known collectively as [Dibba](/wiki/Dibba "Dibba") are the
gateway to the Musandam peninsula on land and the fishing villages of Musandam
by sea, with boats available for hire at Khasab for trips into the Musandam
peninsula by sea. Oman's other exclave, inside UAE territory, known as
[Madha](/wiki/Madha "Madha"), located halfway between the Musandam Peninsula
and the main body of Oman,[42] is part of the Musandam governorate, covering
approximately 75 km2 (29 sq mi). Madha's boundary was settled in 1969, with
the north-east corner of Madha barely 10 m (32.8 ft) from the
[Fujairah](/wiki/Fujairah "Fujairah") road. Within the Madha exclave is a UAE
[enclave](/wiki/Enclave "Enclave") called [Nahwa](/wiki/Nahwa "Nahwa"),
belonging to the [Emirate of Sharjah](/wiki/Emirate_of_Sharjah "Emirate of
Sharjah"). Situated about 8 km (5 mi) along a dirt track west of the town of
New Madha, consisting of about forty houses with a clinic and telephone
exchange.[43] The central desert of Oman is an important source of
[meteorites](/wiki/Meteorites "Meteorites") for scientific analysis.[44]

### Climate

Main article: [Climate of Oman](/wiki/Climate_of_Oman "Climate of Oman")

Like the rest of the Persian Gulf, Oman generally has one of the hottest
climates in the world—with summer temperatures in Muscat and northern Oman
averaging 30 °C (86.0 °F) to 40 °C (104.0 °F).[45] Oman receives [little
rainfall](/wiki/Geography_of_Oman "Geography of Oman"), with annual rainfall
in Muscat averaging 100 mm (3.9 in), falling mostly in January. In the south,
the [Dhofar](/wiki/Dhofar "Dhofar") Mountains area near Salalah has a
tropical-like climate and receives seasonal rainfall from late June to late
September as a result of monsoon winds from the Indian Ocean, leaving the
summer air saturated with cool moisture and heavy fog.[46] Summer temperatures
in [Salalah](/wiki/Salalah "Salalah") range from 20 °C (68.0 °F) to 30 °C
(86.0 °F)—relatively cool compared to northern Oman.[47]

The mountain areas receive more rainfall, and annual rainfall on the higher
parts of the [Jabal Akhdar](/wiki/Jabal_Akhdar "Jabal Akhdar") probably
exceeds 400 mm (15.7 in).[48] Low temperatures in the mountainous areas result
in snow cover once every few years.[49] Some parts of the coast, particularly
near the island of [Masirah](/wiki/Masirah "Masirah"), sometimes receive no
rain at all within the course of a year. The climate generally is very hot,
with temperatures reaching around 50 °C (122.0 °F) (peak) in the hot season,
from May to September.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

On June 26, 2018 the city of Quriyat in Oman set the lowest temperature record
(day and night time lowest temperature) with 42.6°C (108.7°F).[50]

### Flora and fauna

See also: [Wildlife of Oman](/wiki/Wildlife_of_Oman "Wildlife of Oman")

[](/wiki/File:Nakhalfarms.jpg "Enlarge")

Nakhal palm tree farms in Oman's [Batina Region](/wiki/Al_Batinah_Region "Al
Batinah Region")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/The-Worlds-Most-
Isolated-and-Distinct-Whale-Population-Humpback-Whales-of-the-Arabian-Sea-
pone.0114162.s001.tif/lossy-page1-220px-The-Worlds-Most-Isolated-and-Distinct-
Whale-Population-Humpback-Whales-of-the-Arabian-Sea-
pone.0114162.s001.tif.jpg)](/wiki/File:The-Worlds-Most-Isolated-and-Distinct-
Whale-Population-Humpback-Whales-of-the-Arabian-Sea-pone.0114162.s001.tif)

[](/wiki/File:The-Worlds-Most-Isolated-and-Distinct-Whale-Population-Humpback-
Whales-of-the-Arabian-Sea-pone.0114162.s001.tif "Enlarge")

The Arabian [humpback whales](/wiki/Humpback_whales "Humpback whales") off
[Dhofar](/wiki/Dhofar "Dhofar")

[Desert shrub](/wiki/Desert_shrub "Desert shrub") and desert grass, common to
southern Arabia, are found in Oman, but vegetation is sparse in the interior
plateau, which is largely [gravel](/wiki/Gravel "Gravel") desert. The greater
monsoon rainfall in Dhofar and the mountains makes the growth there more
luxuriant during summer; [coconut palms](/wiki/Coconut_palm "Coconut palm")
grow plentifully in the coastal plains of Dhofar and
[frankincense](/wiki/Frankincense "Frankincense") is produced in the hills,
with abundant [oleander](/wiki/Oleander "Oleander") and varieties of
[acacia](/wiki/Acacia "Acacia"). The [Al Hajar
Mountains](/wiki/Al_Hajar_Mountains "Al Hajar Mountains") are a distinct
[ecoregion](/wiki/Ecoregion "Ecoregion"), the highest points in eastern Arabia
with [wildlife](/wiki/Wildlife "Wildlife") including the [Arabian
tahr](/wiki/Arabian_tahr "Arabian tahr").

[Indigenous](/wiki/Indigenous_\(ecology\) "Indigenous \(ecology\)")
[mammals](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal") include the [leopard](/wiki/Leopard
"Leopard"), [hyena](/wiki/Hyena "Hyena"), fox, [wolf](/wiki/Wolf "Wolf"),
hare, oryx, and [ibex](/wiki/Ibex "Ibex"). Birds include the vulture, eagle,
stork, bustard, Arabian partridge, bee eater, falcon, and sunbird. In 2001,
Oman had nine endangered species of mammals, five endangered types of
birds,[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] and nineteen threatened [plant species](/wiki/Plant_species "Plant
species"). Decrees have been passed to protect endangered species, including
the [Arabian leopard](/wiki/Arabian_leopard "Arabian leopard"), [Arabian
oryx](/wiki/Arabian_oryx "Arabian oryx"), [mountain
gazelle](/wiki/Mountain_gazelle "Mountain gazelle"), [goitered
gazelle](/wiki/Goitered_gazelle "Goitered gazelle"), [Arabian
tahr](/wiki/Arabian_tahr "Arabian tahr"), [green sea
turtle](/wiki/Green_sea_turtle "Green sea turtle"), [hawksbill
turtle](/wiki/Hawksbill_turtle "Hawksbill turtle"), and [olive ridley
turtle](/wiki/Olive_ridley_turtle "Olive ridley turtle"). However, the
[Arabian Oryx Sanctuary](/wiki/Arabian_Oryx_Sanctuary "Arabian Oryx
Sanctuary") is the first site ever to be deleted from [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO
"UNESCO")'s World Heritage List, due to the government's decision to reduce
the site to 10% of its former size so that the remainder could be opened to
oil prospectors.[51]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Osprey_yiti.jpg/220px-
Osprey_yiti.jpg)](/wiki/File:Osprey_yiti.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Osprey_yiti.jpg "Enlarge")

Osprey in Yiti Beach, Oman

In recent years, Oman has become one of newer hot spots for [whale
watching](/wiki/Whale_watching "Whale watching"), highlighting the critically
endangered Arabian [humpback whale](/wiki/Humpback_whale "Humpback whale"),
the most isolated and only non-[migratory](/wiki/Animal_migration "Animal
migration") population in the world, [sperm whales](/wiki/Sperm_whale "Sperm
whale"), and [pygmy blue whales](/wiki/Pygmy_blue_whale "Pygmy blue
whale").[52]

### Environmental issues

Drought and limited rainfall contribute to shortages in the nation's water
supply. Maintaining an adequate supply of water for agricultural and domestic
use is one of Oman's most pressing environmental problems, with limited
renewable [water resources](/wiki/Water_resources "Water resources"). 94% of
available water is used in farming and 2% for industrial activity, with the
majority sourced from [fossil water](/wiki/Fossil_water "Fossil water") in the
desert areas and spring water in hills and mountains.

Drinking water is available throughout Oman, either piped or delivered. The
soil in coastal plains, such as Salalah, have shown increased levels of
salinity, due to over exploitation of ground water and encroachment by
seawater on the water table. Pollution of beaches and other coastal areas by
oil tanker traffic through the [Strait of Hormuz](/wiki/Strait_of_Hormuz
"Strait of Hormuz") and [Gulf of Oman](/wiki/Gulf_of_Oman "Gulf of Oman") is
also a persistent concern.[53]

Local and national entities have noted unethical treatment of animals in Oman.
In particular, stray dogs (and to a lesser extent, stray cats) are often the
victims of torture, abuse or neglect.[54] Currently, the only approved method
of decreasing the stray dog population is shooting by police officers. The
Oman government has refused to implement a spay and neuter program or create
any animal shelters in the country. Cats, while seen as more acceptable than
dogs, are viewed as pests and frequently die of starvation or illness.[55][56]

## Politics

Main articles: [Politics of Oman](/wiki/Politics_of_Oman "Politics of Oman")
and [Human rights in Oman](/wiki/Human_rights_in_Oman "Human rights in Oman")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Oman-
Muscat-16-Sultans-Palace-2.JPG/220px-Oman-Muscat-16-Sultans-
Palace-2.JPG)](/wiki/File:Oman-Muscat-16-Sultans-Palace-2.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Oman-Muscat-16-Sultans-Palace-2.JPG "Enlarge")

The Sultan's [Al Alam Palace](/wiki/Al_Alam_Palace "Al Alam Palace") in Old
Muscat

Oman is a [unitary state](/wiki/Unitary_state "Unitary state") and an
[absolute monarchy](/wiki/Absolute_monarchy "Absolute monarchy"),[57] in which
all legislative, executive and judiciary power ultimately rests in the hands
of the hereditary Sultan. [Freedom House](/wiki/Freedom_House "Freedom House")
has routinely rated the country "Not Free" as it is an absolute monarchy.[58]

[Sultan Qaboos](/wiki/Qaboos_bin_Said_al_Said "Qaboos bin Said al Said") is
the head of state and also directly controls the foreign affairs and defence
portfolios.[59] The sultan has absolute power and issues [laws by
decree](/wiki/Rule_by_decree "Rule by decree").[60] He is also the longest-
serving ruler in the Middle East.[61]

### Legal system

Oman is an [absolute monarchy](/wiki/Absolute_monarchy "Absolute monarchy"),
with the Sultan's word having the force of law. The judiciary branch is
subordinate to the Sultan. According to Oman's constitution, [Sharia
law](/wiki/Sharia_law "Sharia law") is one of the sources of legislation.
Sharia court departments within the civil court system are responsible for
family-law matters, such as divorce and inheritance.

The country has no system of checks and balances, and thus no [separation of
powers](/wiki/Separation_of_powers "Separation of powers").[8] All power is
concentrated in the Sultan,[8] who is also chief of staff of the armed forces,
Minister of Defence, Minister of Foreign Affairs and chairman of the Central
Bank.[8] All legislation since 1970 has been promulgated through royal
decrees, including the 1996 Basic Law.[8] The Sultan appoints judges, and can
grant pardons and commute sentences.[8] The Sultan's authority is inviolable
and the Sultan expects total subordination to his will.[8]

The administration of justice is highly personalized, with limited due process
protections, especially in political and security-related cases.[62] The
[Basic Statute of the State](/wiki/Basic_Statute_of_Oman "Basic Statute of
Oman")[63] is supposedly the cornerstone of the Omani legal system and it
operates as a constitution for the country. The Basic Statute was issued in
1996 and thus far has only been amended once, in 2011,[64] in response to
[protests](/wiki/2011_Omani_protests "2011 Omani protests").

Though Oman’s legal code theoretically protects civil liberties and personal
freedoms, both are regularly ignored by the regime.[8] Women and children face
legal discrimination in many areas.[8] Women are excluded from certain state
benefits, such as housing loans, and are refused equal rights under the
personal status law.[8] Women also experience restrictions on their self-
determination in respect to health and reproductive rights.[8]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Gates_%26_Qaboos_of_Oman_cropped.jpg/220px-
Gates_%26_Qaboos_of_Oman_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gates_%26_Qaboos_of_Oman_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gates_%26_Qaboos_of_Oman_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

[Qaboos bin Said al Said](/wiki/Qaboos_bin_Said_al_Said "Qaboos bin Said al
Said")

The National Human Rights Commission, established in 2008, is not independent
from the regime.[8] It is chaired by the former deputy inspector general of
Police and Customs and its members are appointed by royal decree.[8] In June
2012, one of its members requested that she be relieved of her duties because
she disagreed with a statement made by the Commission justifying the arrest of
intellectuals and bloggers and the restriction of freedom of expression in the
name of respect for “the principles of religion and customs of the
country”.[8]

Since the beginning of the “Omani Spring” in January 2011, a number of serious
violations of civil rights have been reported, amounting to a critical
deterioration of the human rights situation.[8] Prisons are not accessible to
independent monitors.[8] Members of the independent Omani Group of Human
Rights have been harassed, arrested and sentenced to jail. There have been
numerous testimonies of torture and other inhumane forms of punishment
perpetrated by security forces on protesters and detainees.[8] The detainees
were all peacefully exercising their right to freedom of expression and
assembly.[8] Although authorities must obtain court orders to hold suspects in
pre-trial detention, they do not regularly follow these procedures.[8] The
penal code was amended in October 2011 to allow the arrest and detention of
individuals without an arrest warrant from public prosecutors.[8]

The Omani legislature is the bicameral [Council of Oman](/wiki/Council_of_Oman
"Council of Oman"), consisting of an upper chamber, the [Council of
State](/wiki/Council_of_State_\(Oman\) "Council of State \(Oman\)") (Majlis
ad-Dawlah) and a lower chamber, the [Consultative
Council](/wiki/Consultative_Assembly_of_Oman "Consultative Assembly of Oman")
(Majlis ash-Shoura).[65] Political parties are banned.[61] The upper chamber
has 71 members, appointed by the Sultan from among prominent Omanis; it has
only advisory powers.[66] The 84 members of the Consultative Council are
elected by popular vote to serve four-year terms, but the Sultan makes the
final selections and can negotiate the election results.[66] The members are
appointed for three-year terms, which may be renewed once.[65] The last
elections were held on [October 2011](/wiki/Omani_parliamentary_election,_2011
"Omani parliamentary election, 2011"). Oman's national anthem, _[As-Salam as-
Sultani](/wiki/As-Salam_as-Sultani "As-Salam as-Sultani")_ is dedicated to
Sultan Qaboos.

### Human rights

Main article: [Human rights in Oman](/wiki/Human_rights_in_Oman "Human rights
in Oman")

Oman is an [absolute monarchy](/wiki/Absolute_monarchy "Absolute monarchy") by
[male primogeniture](/wiki/Male_primogeniture "Male primogeniture"). The
present Sultan, [Qaboos bin Said al Said](/wiki/Qaboos_bin_Said_al_Said
"Qaboos bin Said al Said"), has been the hereditary leader of the country
since 1970.

[Homosexual](/wiki/Homosexuality "Homosexuality") acts are illegal in
Oman.[67] The practice of [torture](/wiki/Torture "Torture") is widespread in
Oman state penal institutions and has become the state's typical reaction to
independent political expression.[68][69] Torture methods in use in Oman
include [mock execution](/wiki/Mock_execution "Mock execution"), beating,
[hooding](/wiki/Hooding "Hooding"), solitary confinement, subjection to
extremes of temperature and to constant noise, abuse and humiliation.[68]
There have been numerous reports of torture and other inhumane forms of
punishment perpetrated by Omani security forces on protesters and
detainees.[70] Several prisoners detained in 2012 complained of sleep
deprivation, extreme temperatures, and solitary confinement.[71] Omani
authorities kept Sultan al-Saadi, a social media activist, in solitary
confinement, denied him access to his lawyer and family, forced him to wear a
black bag over his head whenever he left his cell, including when using the
restroom, and told him his family had “forsaken” him and asked for him to be
imprisoned.[71]

The Omani government decides who can or cannot be a journalist and this
permission can be withdrawn at any time.[72] [Censorship](/wiki/Censorship
"Censorship") and [self-censorship](/wiki/Self-censorship "Self-censorship")
are a constant factor.[72] Omanis have limited access to political information
through the media.[73] Access to news and information can be problematic:
journalists have to be content with news compiled by the official news agency
on some issues.[72] Through a decree by the Sultan, the government has now
extended its control over the media to blogs and other websites.[72] Omanis
cannot hold a public meeting without the government's approval.[72] Omanis who
want to set up a [non-governmental organisation](/wiki/Non-
governmental_organisation "Non-governmental organisation") of any kind need a
licence.[72] To get a licence, they have to demonstrate that the organisation
is "for legitimate objectives" and not "inimical to the social order".[72] The
Omani government does not permit the formation of independent [civil
society](/wiki/Civil_society "Civil society") associations.[70]

The law prohibits criticism of the Sultan and government in any form or
medium.[72] Oman's police do not need [search warrants](/wiki/Search_warrants
"Search warrants") in order to enter people's homes.[72] The law does not
provide citizens with the right to change their government.[72] The Sultan
retains ultimate authority on all foreign and domestic issues.[72] Government
officials are not subject to financial disclosure laws.[72] Libel laws and
concerns for national security have been used to suppress criticism of
government figures and politically objectionable views.[72] Publication of
books is limited and the government restricts their importation and
distribution, as with other media products.[72]

Merely mentioning the existence of such restrictions can land Omanis in
trouble.[72] In 2009, a web publisher was fined and given a suspended jail
sentence for revealing that a supposedly live TV programme was actually pre-
recorded in order to eliminate any criticisms of the government.[72]

Faced with so many restrictions, Omanis have resorted to unconventional
methods for expressing their views.[72] Omanis sometimes use
[donkeys](/wiki/Donkey "Donkey") to express their views.[72] Writing about
Gulf rulers in 2001, Dale Eickelman observed: "Only in Oman has the occasional
donkey… been used as a mobile billboard to express anti-regime sentiments.
There is no way in which police can maintain dignity in seizing and destroying
a donkey on whose flank a political message has been inscribed."[72]

Omani citizens need government permission to marry foreigners.[71] The
Ministry of Interior requires Omani citizens to obtain permission to marry
foreigners (except nationals of GCC countries); permission is not
automatically granted.[71] Citizen marriage to a foreigner abroad without
ministry approval may result in denial of entry for the foreign spouse at the
border and preclude children from claiming citizenship rights.[71] It also may
result in a bar from government employment and a fine of 2,000 rials
($5,200).[71]

In August 2014, The Omani writer and human rights defender [Mohammed
Alfazari](/wiki/Mohammed_Alfazari "Mohammed Alfazari"), the founder and
editor-in-chief of the e-magazine Mowatin “Citizen”, disappeared after going
to the police station in the Al-Qurum district of Muscat.[74] For several
months the Omani government denied his detention and refused to disclose
information about his whereabouts or condition.[74] On July 17, 2015, Al
Fazari left Oman seeking political asylum in UK after a travel ban was issued
against him without providing any reasons and after his official documents
including his national ID and passport were confiscated for more than 8
months.[75] There were more reports of politically motivated disappearances in
the country.[71] In 2012, armed security forces arrested Sultan al-Saadi, a
social media activist.[71] According to reports, authorities detained him at
an unknown location for one month for comments he posted online critical of
the government.[71] Authorities previously arrested al-Saadi in 2011 for
participating in protests and again in 2012 for posting comments online deemed
insulting to Sultan Qaboos.[71] In May 2012 security forces detained Ismael
al-Meqbali, Habiba al-Hinai, and Yaqoub al-Kharusi, human rights activists who
were visiting striking oil workers.[71] Authorities released al-Hinai and al-
Kharusi shortly after their detention but did not inform al-Meqbali’s friends
and family of his whereabouts for weeks.[71] Authorities pardoned al-Meqbali
in March.[71] In December 2013, a Yemeni national disappeared in Oman after he
was arrested at a checkpoint in Dhofar Governorate.[76] Omani authorities
refuse to acknowledge his detention.[76] His whereabouts and condition remain
unknown.[76]

The National Human Rights Commission, established in 2008, is not independent
from the regime.[8] It is chaired by the former deputy inspector general of
Police and Customs and its members are appointed by royal decree.[8] In June
2012, one of its members requested that she be relieved of her duties because
she disagreed with a statement made by the Commission justifying the arrest of
intellectuals and bloggers and the restriction of freedom of expression in the
name of respect for “the principles of religion and customs of the
country”.[8]

Since the beginning of the “Omani Spring” in January 2011, a number of serious
violations of civil rights has been reported, amounting to a critical
deterioration of the human rights situation.[8] Prisons are inaccessible to
independent monitors.[8] Members of the independent Omani Group of Human
Rights have been harassed, arrested and sentenced to jail. There have been
numerous testimonies of torture and other inhumane forms of punishment
perpetrated by security forces on protesters and detainees.[8] The detainees
were all peacefully exercising their right to freedom of expression and
assembly.[8] Although authorities must obtain court orders to hold suspects in
pre-trial detention, they do not regularly do this.[8] The penal code was
amended in October 2011 to allow the arrest and detention of individuals
without an arrest warrant from public prosecutors.[8]

In January 2014, Omani intelligence agents arrested a [Bahraini](/wiki/Bahrain
"Bahrain") actor and handed him over to the Bahraini authorities on the same
day of his arrest.[77] The actor has been subjected to a [forced
disappearance](/wiki/Forced_disappearance "Forced disappearance"), his
whereabouts and condition remain unknown.[77]

### Migrant workers

Main article: [Migrant workers in the Gulf
region](/wiki/Migrant_workers_in_the_Gulf_region "Migrant workers in the Gulf
region")

The plight of [domestic workers](/wiki/Domestic_workers "Domestic workers") in
Oman is a taboo subject.[78][79] In 2011, the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines
"Philippines") government determined that out of all the countries in the
Middle East, only Oman and [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel") qualify as safe for
Filipino migrants.[80] In 2012, it was reported that every 6 days, an Indian
migrant in Oman commits suicide.[81][82] There has been a campaign urging
authorities to check the migrant suicide rate.[83] In the 2014 [Global Slavery
Index](/wiki/Global_Slavery_Index "Global Slavery Index"), Oman is ranked #45
due to 26,000 people in [slavery](/wiki/Slavery "Slavery").[84][85] The
descendants of servant tribes and slaves are victims of widespread
discrimination.[70][86] Oman was one of the last countries to [abolish
slavery](/wiki/Abolition_of_slavery_timeline "Abolition of slavery timeline")
in 1970.[79]

### Foreign policy

Main article: [Foreign relations of Oman](/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Oman
"Foreign relations of Oman")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Secretary_Kerry_Walks_With_Omani_Qaboos_bin_Said_Al_Said.jpg/220px-
Secretary_Kerry_Walks_With_Omani_Qaboos_bin_Said_Al_Said.jpg)](/wiki/File:Secretary_Kerry_Walks_With_Omani_Qaboos_bin_Said_Al_Said.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Secretary_Kerry_Walks_With_Omani_Qaboos_bin_Said_Al_Said.jpg
"Enlarge")

U.S. Secretary of State [John Kerry](/wiki/John_Kerry "John Kerry") meets with
Sultan Qaboos in Muscat, May 2013

Since 1970, Oman has pursued a moderate foreign policy, and has expanded its
diplomatic relations dramatically. Oman is among the very few Arab countries
that have maintained friendly ties with [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran").[87][88]
[WikiLeaks](/wiki/WikiLeaks "WikiLeaks") disclosed US diplomatic cables which
state that Oman helped free British sailors captured by Iran's navy in
2007.[89] The same cables also portray the Omani government as wishing to
maintain cordial relations with Iran, and as having consistently resisted US
diplomatic pressure to adopt a sterner stance.[90][91][92] [Yusuf bin Alawi
bin Abdullah](/wiki/Yusuf_bin_Alawi_bin_Abdullah "Yusuf bin Alawi bin
Abdullah") is the Sultanate's Minister Responsible for Foreign Affairs.

### Military

Main article: [Sultan of Oman's Armed
Forces](/wiki/Sultan_of_Oman%27s_Armed_Forces "Sultan of Oman's Armed Forces")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Portsmouth_korvet_Al-
Shamikh_Oman_18-10-2011_15-15-51.png/300px-Portsmouth_korvet_Al-
Shamikh_Oman_18-10-2011_15-15-51.png)](/wiki/File:Portsmouth_korvet_Al-
Shamikh_Oman_18-10-2011_15-15-51.png)

[](/wiki/File:Portsmouth_korvet_Al-Shamikh_Oman_18-10-2011_15-15-51.png
"Enlarge")

The [Khareef-class corvette](/wiki/Khareef-class_corvette "Khareef-class
corvette"), Al-Shamikh

Oman's military manpower totalled 44,100 in 2006, including 25,000 men in the
army, 4,200 sailors in the navy, and an air force with 4,100 personnel. The
[Royal Household](/wiki/Royal_Household "Royal Household") maintained 5,000
Guards, 1,000 in Special Forces, 150 sailors in the Royal Yacht fleet, and 250
pilots and ground personnel in the Royal Flight squadrons. Oman also maintains
a modestly sized paramilitary force of 4,400 men.[93]

The [Royal Army of Oman](/wiki/Royal_Army_of_Oman "Royal Army of Oman") had
25,000 active personnel in 2006, plus a small contingent of Royal Household
troops. Despite a comparative large military spending, it has been relatively
slow to modernize its forces. Oman has a relatively limited number of tanks,
including 6 [M60A1](/wiki/M60A1 "M60A1"), 73 [M60A3](/wiki/M60A3 "M60A3"), and
38 [Challenger 2](/wiki/Challenger_2 "Challenger 2") main battle tanks, as
well as 37 aging [Scorpion](/wiki/FV101_Scorpion "FV101 Scorpion") light
tanks.[93]

The [Royal Air Force of Oman](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force_of_Oman "Royal Air Force
of Oman") has approximately 4,100 men, with only 36 combat aircraft and no
armed helicopters. Combat aircraft include 20 aging
[Jaguars](/wiki/SEPECAT_Jaguar "SEPECAT Jaguar"), 12
[Hawk](/wiki/BAE_Systems_Hawk "BAE Systems Hawk") Mk 203s, 4 Hawk Mk 103s, and
12 [PC-9](/wiki/PC-9 "PC-9") turboprop trainers with a limited combat
capability. It has one squadron of 12 [F-16C/D](/wiki/F-16 "F-16") aircraft.
Oman also has 4 [A202-18 Bravos](/wiki/FFA_AS-202_Bravo "FFA AS-202 Bravo"),
and 8 [MFI-17B Mushshaqs](/wiki/PAC_MFI-17_Mushshak "PAC MFI-17
Mushshak").[93]

The [Royal Navy of Oman](/wiki/Royal_Navy_of_Oman "Royal Navy of Oman") had
4,200 men in 2000, and is headquartered at [Seeb](/wiki/Seeb "Seeb"). It has
bases at Ahwi, Ghanam Island, [Mussandam](/wiki/Mussandam "Mussandam") and
[Salalah](/wiki/Salalah "Salalah"). In 2006, Oman had 10 surface combat
vessels. These included two 1,450-ton [_Qahir_ class](/wiki/Qahir-
class_corvette "Qahir-class corvette") [corvettes](/wiki/Corvette "Corvette"),
and 8 ocean-going [patrol boats](/wiki/Patrol_boat "Patrol boat"). The Omani
Navy had one 2,500-ton [_Nasr al Bahr_ class](/wiki/Nasr_al_Bahr_\(L2\) "Nasr
al Bahr \(L2\)") LSL (240 troops, 7 tanks) with a helicopter deck. Oman also
had at least four [landing craft](/wiki/Landing_craft "Landing craft").[93]
Oman ordered three [_Khareef_ class](/wiki/Khareef-class_corvette "Khareef-
class corvette") corvettes from the [VT Group](/wiki/VT_Group "VT Group") for
£400 million in 2007. They are being built at [Portsmouth](/wiki/Portsmouth
"Portsmouth").[94] In 2010 Oman spent US$4.074 billion on military
expenditures, 8.5% [of the gross domestic
product](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditure_share_of_GDP "List of
countries by military expenditure share of GDP").[95] The sultanate has a long
history of association with the British military and defence industry.[96]
According to [SIPRI](/wiki/SIPRI "SIPRI"), Oman was the 23rd largest arms
importer from 2012–2016.[97]

## Economy

Main article: [Economy of Oman](/wiki/Economy_of_Oman "Economy of Oman")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Oman_Export_Treemap.png/300px-
Oman_Export_Treemap.png)](/wiki/File:Oman_Export_Treemap.png)

[](/wiki/File:Oman_Export_Treemap.png "Enlarge")

A proportional representation of Oman's exports

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9c/MSM_Main.JPG/220px-
MSM_Main.JPG)](/wiki/File:MSM_Main.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:MSM_Main.JPG "Enlarge")

[Muscat Securities Market](/wiki/Muscat_Securities_Market "Muscat Securities
Market")

Oman's Basic Statute of the State expresses in Article 11 that the "national
economy is based on justice and the principles of a [free
economy](/wiki/Market_economy "Market economy")."[100] By regional standards,
Oman has a relatively diversified economy, but remains dependent on oil
exports. Tourism is the fastest-growing industry in Oman. Other sources of
income, agriculture and industry, are small in comparison and account for less
than 1% of the country's exports, but diversification is seen as a priority by
the government. Agriculture, often [subsistence](/wiki/Subsistence
"Subsistence") in its character, produces [dates](/wiki/Phoenix_dactylifera
"Phoenix dactylifera"), [limes](/wiki/Lime_\(fruit\) "Lime \(fruit\)"),
[grains](/wiki/Cereal "Cereal"), and vegetables, but with less than 1% of the
country under [cultivation](/wiki/Tillage "Tillage"), Oman is likely to remain
a net importer of food.

Since a slump in oil prices in 1998, Oman has made active plans to diversify
its economy and is placing a greater emphasis on other areas of industry,
namely tourism and infrastructure.

A [free-trade agreement with the United
States](/wiki/Oman%E2%80%93United_States_Free_Trade_Agreement "Oman–United
States Free Trade Agreement") took effect 1 January 2009, eliminated tariff
barriers on all consumer and industrial products, and also provided strong
protections for foreign businesses investing in Oman.[101]
[Tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_Oman "Tourism in Oman"), another source of Oman's
revenue, is on the rise.[102] A popular event is The Khareef Festival held in
[Salalah](/wiki/Salalah "Salalah"), [Dhofar](/wiki/Dhofar "Dhofar"), which is
1,200 km from the capital city of Muscat, during the monsoon season (August)
and is similar to Muscat Festival. During this latter event the mountains
surrounding Salalah are popular with tourists as a result of the cool weather
and lush greenery, rarely found anywhere else in Oman.[103]

Oman's [foreign workers](/wiki/Migrant_workers_in_the_Gulf_region "Migrant
workers in the Gulf region") send an estimated US$30 billion annually to their
home states in Asia and Africa, more than half of them earning a monthly wage
of less than US$400.[104] The largest foreign community is from the Indian
states of [Kerala](/wiki/Kerala "Kerala"), [Tamil Nadu](/wiki/Tamil_Nadu
"Tamil Nadu"), [Karnataka](/wiki/Karnataka "Karnataka"),
[Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra"), [Gujarat](/wiki/Gujarat
"Gujarat") and the [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab,_India "Punjab, India"),[105]
representing more than half of entire workforce in Oman. Salaries for overseas
workers are known to be less than for Omani nationals, though still from two
to five times higher than for the equivalent job in [India](/wiki/India
"India").[104]

The Oman Ferries Company maintains the two diesel-powered, high-speed, car
ferries – Shinas and Hormouz. The ferries are used for travel between
[Muscat](/wiki/Muscat,_Oman "Muscat, Oman") and [Khasab](/wiki/Khasab
"Khasab"). Khasab is strategically located in
[Musandam](/wiki/Musandam_Peninsula "Musandam Peninsula") on the southern tip
of the [Strait of Hormuz](/wiki/Strait_of_Hormuz "Strait of Hormuz") and is
controlled by Oman. Mainland Oman is separated by a small strip of
[UAE](/wiki/UAE "UAE") territory from Musandam.

### Oil and gas

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Sohar_flickr01.jpg/220px-
Sohar_flickr01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sohar_flickr01.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sohar_flickr01.jpg "Enlarge")

Petrochemical tanks in [Sohar](/wiki/Sohar "Sohar")

Oman's proved reserves of petroleum total about 5.5 billion barrels, 25th
largest in the world.[87] Oil is extracted and processed by [Petroleum
Development Oman](/wiki/Petroleum_Development_Oman "Petroleum Development
Oman") (PDO), with proven oil reserves holding approximately steady, although
oil production has been declining.[106][107] The [Ministry of Oil and
Gas](/wiki/Ministry_of_Oil_and_Gas_\(Oman\) "Ministry of Oil and Gas
\(Oman\)") is responsible for all oil and gas infrastructure and projects in
Oman.[108] Following the [1970s energy crisis](/wiki/1970s_energy_crisis
"1970s energy crisis"), Oman doubled their oil output between 1979 and
1985.[109]

Between 2000 and 2007, production fell by more than 26%, from 972,000 to
714,800 [barrels per day](/wiki/Barrels_per_day "Barrels per day").[110]
Production has recovered to 816,000 barrels in 2009, and 930,000 barrels per
day in 2012.[110] Oman's natural gas reserves are estimated at 849.5 billion
cubic meters, ranking 28th in the world, and production in 2008 was about 24
billion cubic meters per year.[87]

### Tourism

Main article: [Tourism in Oman](/wiki/Tourism_in_Oman "Tourism in Oman")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Wahiba_Sands_%2833%29.jpg/220px-
Wahiba_Sands_%2833%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wahiba_Sands_\(33\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wahiba_Sands_\(33\).jpg "Enlarge")

Bustan-palace.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bustan-palace.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bustan-palace.jpg "Enlarge")

Bustan Palace

Tourism in Oman has grown considerably recently, and it is expected to be one
of the largest industries in the country.[111] The World Travel & Tourism
Council stated that Oman is the fastest growing tourism destination in the
Middle East.[112]

Oman has one of the most diverse environments in the Middle East with various
tourist attractions and is particularly well known for adventure and [cultural
tourism](/wiki/Cultural_tourism "Cultural tourism").[102][113]
[Muscat](/wiki/Muscat "Muscat"), the capital of Oman, was named the second
best city to visit in the world in 2012 by the travel guide publisher [Lonely
Planet](/wiki/Lonely_Planet "Lonely Planet").[114] Muscat also was chosen as
the Capital of Arab Tourism of 2012.[115]

## Demographics

Main article: [Demographics of Oman](/wiki/Demographics_of_Oman "Demographics
of Oman")

As of 2014[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oman&action=edit),
Oman's population is over 4 million, with 2.23 million Omani nationals and
1.76 million expatriates.[116] The [total fertility
rate](/wiki/Total_fertility_rate "Total fertility rate") in 2011 was estimated
at 3.70.[117] Oman has a very young population, with 43 percent of its
inhabitants under the age of 15. Nearly 50 percent of the population lives in
[Muscat](/wiki/Muscat,_Oman "Muscat, Oman") and the [Batinah coastal
plain](/wiki/Batinah "Batinah") northwest of the capital. [Omani
people](/wiki/Omani_people "Omani people") are predominantly of
[Arab](/wiki/Arabs "Arabs"), [Baluchi](/wiki/Baloch_people "Baloch people")
and [African](/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa "Ethnic groups of Africa")
origins.[87]

Omani society is largely [tribal](/wiki/Tribal "Tribal")[86][118][119] and
encompasses three major identities:[86] that of the tribe, the Ibadi faith,
and maritime trade.[86] The first two identities are closely tied to tradition
and are especially prevalent in the interior of the country, owing to lengthy
periods of isolation.[86] The third identity pertains mostly to Muscat and the
coastal areas of Oman, and is reflected by business, [trade](/wiki/Trade
"Trade"),[86] and the diverse origins of many Omanis, who trace their roots to
Baloch, [Al-Lawatia](/wiki/Al-Lawatia "Al-Lawatia"),
[Persia](/wiki/Persian_people "Persian people"), and historical Omani
[Zanzibar](/wiki/Zanzibar "Zanzibar").[120] Consequently, the third identity
is generally seen to be more open and tolerant towards others,[86] and is
often in tension with the more traditional and insular identities of the
interior.[86]

### Religion

Main article: [Islam in Oman](/wiki/Islam_in_Oman "Islam in Oman")

Further information: [Freedom of religion in
Oman](/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Oman "Freedom of religion in Oman")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/SultanQaboosGrandMosque-
Meifen1.JPG/220px-SultanQaboosGrandMosque-
Meifen1.JPG)](/wiki/File:SultanQaboosGrandMosque-Meifen1.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:SultanQaboosGrandMosque-Meifen1.JPG "Enlarge")

[Sultan Qaboos Grand Mosque](/wiki/Sultan_Qaboos_Grand_Mosque "Sultan Qaboos
Grand Mosque")

Religion in Oman (2010)[121]

[Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam") (85.9%)

[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") (6.5%)

[Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism") (5.5%)

Others (1%)

[Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism") (0.8%)

Unaffiliated (0.2%)

[Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism") (0.1%)

Islam (official; majority are Ibadi and less Sunni and Shia) 85.9%, Christian
6.5%, Hindu 5.5%, Buddhist 0.8%, Jewish <0.1, Other 1%, Unaffiliated 0.2%.

The Oman government does not keep statistics on religious affiliation, but
virtually all Omanis are [Muslims](/wiki/Islam "Islam"), most of whom follow
the [Ibadi](/wiki/Ibadi "Ibadi") School of Islam, followed by the
[Shafi`i](/wiki/Shafi%60i "Shafi`i") school of [Sunni Islam](/wiki/Sunni_Islam
"Sunni Islam"). Virtually all non-Muslims in Oman are foreign workers. Non-
Muslim religious communities include various groups of [Jains](/wiki/Jainism
"Jainism"), [Buddhists](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism"),
[Zoroastrians](/wiki/Zoroastrianism "Zoroastrianism"), [Sikhs](/wiki/Sikhism
"Sikhism"), [Jews](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"), [Hindus](/wiki/Hinduism
"Hinduism") and [Christians](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"). Christian
communities are centred in the major urban areas of
[Muscat](/wiki/Muscat,_Oman "Muscat, Oman"), [Sohar](/wiki/Sohar "Sohar"), and
[Salalah](/wiki/Salalah "Salalah"). These include
[Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church"), [Eastern
Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church "Eastern Orthodox Church"), and
various [Protestant](/wiki/Protestantism "Protestantism") congregations,
organizing along linguistic and ethnic lines. More than 50 different Christian
groups, fellowships, and assemblies are active in the Muscat metropolitan
area, formed by migrant workers from [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia
"Southeast Asia").

There are also communities of ethnic [Indian](/wiki/Indian_people "Indian
people") [Hindus](/wiki/Hindus "Hindus") and Christians. Muscat has two Hindu
temples. One of them is over a hundred years old. There is a significant
[Sikh](/wiki/Sikh "Sikh") community in Oman. Though there are no permanent
[gurdwaras](/wiki/Gurdwara "Gurdwara"), many smaller gurdwaras in makeshift
camps exist and are recognised by the government. The Government of India had
signed an accord in 2008 with the Omani government to build a permanent
gurdwara but little progress has been made on the matter.[122]

### Languages

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Sultan_Qaboos_Highway.jpg/250px-
Sultan_Qaboos_Highway.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sultan_Qaboos_Highway.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sultan_Qaboos_Highway.jpg "Enlarge")

Arabic and English Road Sign in Oman

[Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language") is the official language of
Oman. It belongs to the [Semitic](/wiki/Semitic_languages "Semitic languages")
branch of the [Afroasiatic](/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages "Afroasiatic
languages") family.[100] Prior to Islam, Central Oman lay outside of the core
area of spoken Arabic. Possibly [Old South Arabian](/wiki/Old_South_Arabian
"Old South Arabian") speakers dwelled from the
[Bāṭinah](/w/index.php?title=B%C4%81%E1%B9%ADinah&action=edit&redlink=1
"Bāṭinah \(page does not exist\)") to [Ẓafār](/wiki/Zafar,_Yemen "Zafar,
Yemen").[123] Rare [Musnad](/wiki/Ancient_South_Arabian_script "Ancient South
Arabian script") inscriptions have come to light in central Oman and in the
Emirate of Sharjah, but the script says nothing about the language which it
conveys.[124] A bilingual text from the 3rd century BCE is written in Aramaic
and in musnad [Hasiatic](/w/index.php?title=Hasiatic&action=edit&redlink=1
"Hasiatic \(page does not exist\)"), which mentions a 'king of Oman' (mālk mn
ʿmn).[125] Today the [Mehri language](/wiki/Mehri_language "Mehri language")
is limited in its distribution to the area around
[Ṣalālah](/w/index.php?title=%E1%B9%A2al%C4%81lah&action=edit&redlink=1
"Ṣalālah \(page does not exist\)") in [Ẓafār](/wiki/Zafar,_Yemen "Zafar,
Yemen") and westward into the Yemen. But until the 18th or 19th century it was
spoken further north, perhaps into Central Oman.[126]
[Baluchi](/wiki/Baluchi_language "Baluchi language") ([Southern
Baluchi](/wiki/Southern_Baluchi_language "Southern Baluchi language")) is
widely spoken in Oman.[127] Endangered indigenous languages in Oman include
[Kumzari](/wiki/Kumzari_language "Kumzari language"),
[Bathari](/wiki/Bathari_language "Bathari language"),
[Harsusi](/wiki/Harsusi_language "Harsusi language"),
[Hobyot](/wiki/Hobyot_language "Hobyot language"),
[Jibbali](/wiki/Jibbali_language "Jibbali language") and
[Mehri](/wiki/Mehri_language "Mehri language").[128] [Omani Sign
Language](/wiki/Omani_Sign_Language "Omani Sign Language") is the language of
the deaf community. Oman was also the first [Arab country in the Persian
Gulf](/wiki/Arab_States_of_the_Persian_Gulf "Arab States of the Persian Gulf")
to have German taught as a second language.[129] The Bedouin Arabs, who
reached eastern and south-eastern Arabia in migrational waves -the latest in
the 18th century, brought their language and rule including the ruling
families of Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates.[130] At the most
basic level, there are two kinds of dialects, those of settlers and those of
Bedouin which share some features. Omani dialects preserve much vocabulary
which has been lost in other Arabic dialects. C. Holes has argued convincingly
that Omani Arabic has indigenous characteristics of its own which do not
derive from Bedouin central Arabia. They are better preserved than in
neighbouring countries.

According to the CIA, besides Arabic, [English](/wiki/English_language
"English language"), Baluchi (Southern Baluchi), [Urdu](/wiki/Urdu "Urdu"),
and various Indian languages are the main languages spoken in Oman.[87]
English is widely spoken in the business community and is taught at school
from an early age. Almost all signs and writings appear in both Arabic and
English at tourist sites.[102] Baluchi is the mother tongue of the [Baloch
people](/wiki/Baloch_people "Baloch people") from
[Balochistan](/wiki/Balochistan "Balochistan") in
western-[Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"), eastern [Iran](/wiki/Iran
"Iran"), and southern [Afghanistan](/wiki/Afghanistan "Afghanistan"). It is
also used by some descendants of [Sindhi](/wiki/Sindhi_people "Sindhi people")
sailors.[131] A significant number of residents also speak
[Urdu](/wiki/Urdu_language "Urdu language"), due to the influx of Pakistani
migrants during the late 1980s and 1990s. Additionally,
[Swahili](/wiki/Swahili_language "Swahili language") is widely spoken in the
country due to the historical relations between Oman and
[Zanzibar](/wiki/Zanzibar "Zanzibar").[7]
