## Culture

Main article: [Culture of Oman](/wiki/Culture_of_Oman "Culture of Oman")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/DhowMuscat.jpg/220px-
DhowMuscat.jpg)](/wiki/File:DhowMuscat.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DhowMuscat.jpg "Enlarge")

The traditional [Dhow](/wiki/Dhow "Dhow"), an enduring symbol of Oman[132]

Outwardly, Oman shares many of the cultural characteristics of its Arab
neighbours, particularly those in the [Gulf Cooperation
Council](/wiki/Gulf_Cooperation_Council "Gulf Cooperation Council").[133]
Despite these similarities, important factors make Oman unique in the Middle
East.[133] These result as much from geography and history as from culture and
economics.[133] The relatively recent and artificial nature of the
[state](/wiki/State_\(polity\) "State \(polity\)") in Oman makes it difficult
to describe a national culture;[133] however, sufficient cultural
heterogeneity exists within its national boundaries to make Oman distinct from
other Arab States of the Persian Gulf.[133] Oman's cultural diversity is
greater than that of its Arab neighbours, given its historical expansion to
the Swahili Coast and the Indian Ocean.[133]

Oman has a long tradition of shipbuilding, as maritime travel played a major
role in the Omanis' ability to stay in contact with the civilisations of the
ancient world. [Sur](/wiki/Sur,_Oman "Sur, Oman") was one of the most famous
shipbuilding cities of the Indian Ocean. The Al Ghanja ship takes one whole
year to build. Other types of Omani ship include As Sunbouq and Al Badan.[134]

In March 2016 archaeologists working off Al Hallaniyah Island identified a
shipwreck believed to be that of the _Esmeralda_ from [Vasco da
Gama](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama "Vasco da Gama")'s 1502–1503 fleet. The wreck was
initially discovered in 1998. Later underwater excavations took place between
2013 and 2015 through a partnership between the Oman Ministry of Heritage and
Culture and Bluewater Recoveries Ltd., a shipwreck recovery company. The
vessel was identified through such artifacts as a "Portuguese coin minted for
trade with India (one of only two coins of this type known to exist) and stone
cannonballs engraved with what appear to be the initials of Vincente Sodré, da
Gama's maternal uncle and the commander of the _Esmeralda_."[135]

### Dress

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Khanjar.jpg/170px-
Khanjar.jpg)](/wiki/File:Khanjar.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Khanjar.jpg "Enlarge")

A [khanjar](/wiki/Khanjar "Khanjar"), the traditional [dagger](/wiki/Dagger
"Dagger") of Oman ([c.](/wiki/Circa "Circa") 1924)

The male [national dress](/wiki/National_dress "National dress") in Oman
consists of the _[dishdasha](/wiki/Dishdasha "Dishdasha")_ , a simple, ankle-
length, collarless gown with long sleeves.[75] Most frequently white in
colour, the dishdasha may also appear in a variety of other colours. Its main
adornment, a [tassel](/wiki/Tassel "Tassel") (_furakha_) sewn into the
neckline, can be impregnated with perfume.[136] Underneath the dishdasha, men
wear a plain, wide strip of cloth wrapped around the body from the waist down.
The most noted regional differences in dishdasha designs are the style with
which they are embroidered, which varies according to age group.[75] On formal
occasions a black or beige cloak called a [_bisht_](/wiki/Bisht_\(clothing\)
"Bisht \(clothing\)") may cover the dishdasha. The embroidery edging the cloak
is often in silver or gold thread and it is intricate in detail.[136]

Omani men wear two types of headdress:

  * the _ghutra_ , also called “Musar” a square piece of woven wool or cotton fabric of a single colour, decorated with various embroidered patterns.
  * the _kummah_ , a cap that is the head dress worn during leisure hours.[75]

Some men carry the _assa_ , a stick, which can have practical uses or is
simply used as an accessory during formal events. Omani men, on the whole,
wear sandals on their feet.[136]

The _[khanjar](/wiki/Khanjar "Khanjar")_ (dagger) forms part of the national
dress and men wear the khanjar on all formal public occasions and
festivals.[75] It is traditionally worn at the waist. Sheaths may vary from
simple covers to ornate silver or gold-decorated pieces.[136] It is a symbol
of a man's origin, his manhood and courage. A depiction of a khanjar appears
on the national flag.[75]

Omani women wear eye-catching national costumes, with distinctive regional
variations. All costumes incorporate vivid colours and vibrant embroidery and
decorations. In the past, the choice of colours reflected a tribe's tradition.
The Omani women's traditional costume comprises several garments: the
_kandoorah_ , which is a long tunic whose sleeves or _radoon_ are adorned with
hand-stitched embroidery of various designs. The _dishdasha_ is worn over a
pair of loose fitting trousers, tight at the ankles, known as a
_[sirwal](/wiki/Sirwal "Sirwal")_. Women also wear a head shawl most commonly
referred to as the _lihaf_.[137]

As of 2014[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oman&action=edit)
women reserve wearing their traditional dress for special occasions, and
instead wear a loose black cloak called an _[abaya](/wiki/Abaya "Abaya")_ over
their personal choice of clothing, whilst in some regions, particularly
amongst the Bedouin, the _[burqa](/wiki/Burqa "Burqa")_ is still worn.[137]
Women wear _[hijab](/wiki/Hijab "Hijab")_ , and though some women cover their
faces and hands, most do not. The Sultan has forbidden the covering of faces
in public office.[132]

### Music and cinema

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Final_Curtain_%2817591083699%29.jpg/220px-
Final_Curtain_%2817591083699%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Final_Curtain_\(17591083699\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Final_Curtain_\(17591083699\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Royal Opera House Muscat](/wiki/Royal_Opera_House_Muscat "Royal Opera House
Muscat")

[Music of Oman](/wiki/Music_of_Oman "Music of Oman") is extremely diverse due
to Oman's imperial legacy. There are over 130 different forms of traditional
Omani songs and dances. The Oman Centre for Traditional Music was established
in 1984 to preserve them.[138] In 1985, Sultan Qaboos founded the Royal Oman
Symphony Orchestra, an act attributed[_[by
whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] to his love for classical music.
Instead of engaging foreign musicians, he decided to establish an orchestra
made up of Omanis.[139] On 1 July 1987 at the Al Bustan Palace Hotel's Oman
Auditorium the Royal Oman Symphony Orchestra gave its inaugural concert.[140]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Sur-
Cinema_%283%29.JPG/220px-Sur-Cinema_%283%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sur-
Cinema_\(3\).JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Sur-Cinema_\(3\).JPG "Enlarge")

Cinema in Sur

The [cinema of Oman](/wiki/Cinema_of_Oman "Cinema of Oman") is very small,
there being only one Omani film _Al-Boom_ (2006) as of
2007[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oman&action=edit). Oman
Arab Cinema Company LLC is the single largest motion picture exhibitor chain
in Oman. It belongs to the Jawad Sultan Group of Companies, which has a
history spanning more than 40 years in the Sultanate of Oman.[141] In popular
music, a seven-minute music video about Oman went viral, achieving 500,000
views on YouTube within 10 days of being released on YouTube in November 2015.
The a cappella production features three of the region's most popular talents:
Kahliji musician Al Wasmi, Omani poet Mazin Al-Haddabi and actress Buthaina Al
Raisi.[142]

### Media

[Sultanate of Oman Television](/wiki/Sultanate_of_Oman_Television "Sultanate
of Oman Television") began broadcasting for the first time from Muscat on 17
November 1974 and separately from [Salalah](/wiki/Salalah "Salalah") on 25
November 1975. On 1 June 1979, the two stations at Muscat and Salalah linked
by satellite to form a unified broadcasting service. In order to overcome the
natural obstacles created by the mountainous terrain, a network of stations
spread across the country in both populated and remote areas transmit Oman
TV's broadcasts.[143]

Oman has fewer restrictions on independent media than its neighbors [Saudi
Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi Arabia") or [Yemen](/wiki/Yemen "Yemen").
The press freedom group [Reporters Without
Borders](/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders "Reporters Without Borders") ranked
the country 125th out of 180 countries on its [2016 World Press Freedom
Index](https://rsf.org/en/ranking), one spot below Zimbabwe. However, in 2016,
the government drew international criticism for closing the newspaper
[Azamn](/wiki/Azamn "Azamn") and arresting three journalists after a report
about corruption in the country's judiciary.

### Food

Main article: [Omani cuisine](/wiki/Omani_cuisine "Omani cuisine")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Traditional_Omani_Food.jpg/220px-
Traditional_Omani_Food.jpg)](/wiki/File:Traditional_Omani_Food.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Traditional_Omani_Food.jpg "Enlarge")

Traditional Omani Food

Omani cuisine is diverse and has been influenced by many cultures. Omanis
usually eat their main daily meal at midday, while the evening meal is
lighter. During [Ramadan](/wiki/Ramadan "Ramadan"), dinner is served after the
[Taraweeh](/wiki/Taraweeh "Taraweeh") prayers, sometimes as late as 11 pm.
However these dinner timings differ according to each family – for instance,
some families would choose to eat right after [maghrib](/wiki/Maghrib
"Maghrib") prayers and have dessert after taraweeh.

Arsia, a festival meal served during celebrations, consists of mashed rice and
meat (sometimes chicken). Another popular festival meal, shuwa, consists of
meat cooked very slowly (sometimes for up to 2 days) in an underground clay-
oven. The meat becomes extremely tender and it is infused with spices and
herbs before cooking to give it a very distinct taste. Fish is often used in
main dishes too, and the [kingfish](/wiki/Giant_trevally "Giant trevally") is
a popular ingredient. Mashuai is a meal consisting of a whole spit-roasted
kingfish served with lemon rice.

Rukhal bread is a thin, round bread originally baked over a fire made from
palm leaves. It is eaten at any meal, typically served with Omani honey for
breakfast or crumbled over curry for dinner. Chicken, fish, and lamb or mutton
are regularly used in dishes. The Omani [halwa](/wiki/Halva "Halva") is a very
popular sweet, basically consisting of cooked raw sugar with nuts. There are
many different flavors, the most popular ones being the black halwa (original)
and the saffron halwa. Halwa is considered as a symbol of Omani hospitality,
and is traditionally served with coffee. As is the case with most [Arab States
of the Persian Gulf](/wiki/Arab_States_of_the_Persian_Gulf "Arab States of the
Persian Gulf"), alcohol is only available over-the-counter to non-Muslims.
Muslims can still purchase alcoholic drinks. Alcohol is served in many hotels
and a few restaurants.

### Sports

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/MuscatGulfCup2.jpg/220px-
MuscatGulfCup2.jpg)](/wiki/File:MuscatGulfCup2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MuscatGulfCup2.jpg "Enlarge")

Oman hosted and won the [19th Arabian Gulf Cup](/wiki/19th_Arabian_Gulf_Cup
"19th Arabian Gulf Cup")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Flickr_-
_tpower1978_-_World_Cup_Qualifiers_%287%29.jpg/220px-Flickr_-
_tpower1978_-_World_Cup_Qualifiers_%287%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Flickr_-
_tpower1978_-_World_Cup_Qualifiers_\(7\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Flickr_-_tpower1978_-_World_Cup_Qualifiers_\(7\).jpg "Enlarge")

2010 FIFA World Cup Qualifiers Round 3 match between Oman and Japan at the
Royal Oman Police Stadium on June 7, 2008 in Muscat, Oman

In October 2004, the Omani government set up a [Ministry of Sports
Affairs](/w/index.php?title=Ministry_of_Sports_Affairs&action=edit&redlink=1
"Ministry of Sports Affairs \(page does not exist\)") to replace the General
Organization for youth, sports and cultural affairs. The [19th Arabian Gulf
Cup](/wiki/19th_Arabian_Gulf_Cup "19th Arabian Gulf Cup"), the 19th edition,
took place in [Muscat](/wiki/Muscat,_Oman "Muscat, Oman"), from 4 to 17
January 2009 and was won by the [Omani national football
team](/wiki/Oman_national_football_team "Oman national football team"). The
[23rd Arabian Gulf Cup](/wiki/23rd_Arabian_Gulf_Cup "23rd Arabian Gulf Cup"),
the 23rd edition, that took place in [Kuwait](/wiki/Kuwait "Kuwait"), from 22
December 2017 until January 5th 2018. [Oman](/wiki/Oman_national_football_team
"Oman national football team") won their second title, defeating the [United
Arab Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates_national_football_team "United Arab
Emirates national football team") in the final on penalties following a
goalless draw.

Oman's traditional sports are [dhow](/wiki/Dhow "Dhow") racing, [horse
racing](/wiki/Horse_racing "Horse racing"), [camel racing](/wiki/Camel_racing
"Camel racing"), [bull fighting](/wiki/Bull_fighting "Bull fighting") and
[falconry](/wiki/Falconry "Falconry").[144] [Association
football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football"),
[basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), [waterskiing](/wiki/Waterskiing
"Waterskiing") and [sandboarding](/wiki/Sandboarding "Sandboarding") are among
the sports that have emerged quickly and gained popularity among the younger
generation.[144]

[Ali Al-Habsi](/wiki/Ali_Al-Habsi "Ali Al-Habsi") is an Omani professional
association football player. As of
2015[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oman&action=edit), he
plays in the [Football League Championship](/wiki/Football_League_Championship
"Football League Championship") as a
[goalkeeper](/wiki/Goalkeeper_\(football\) "Goalkeeper \(football\)") for
[Reading](/wiki/Reading_F.C. "Reading F.C.").[145] The [International Olympic
Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic
Committee")
awarded[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] the former GOYSCA its
prestigious prize for Sporting excellence in recognition of its contributions
to youth and sports and its efforts to promote the Olympic spirit and goals.

The [Oman Olympic Committee](/wiki/Oman_Olympic_Committee "Oman Olympic
Committee") played a major part in organizing the highly successful 2003
Olympic Days, which were of great benefit to the sports associations, clubs
and young participants. The [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association
football") association took part, along with the
[handball](/wiki/Team_handball "Team handball"), [basketball](/wiki/Basketball
"Basketball"), [rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union"),
[hockey](/wiki/Hockey "Hockey"), [volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball "Volleyball"),
[athletics](/wiki/Athletics_\(sport\) "Athletics \(sport\)"),
[swimming](/wiki/Swimming_\(sport\) "Swimming \(sport\)"), and
[tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis") associations. In 2010 Muscat hosted the [2010
Asian Beach Games](/wiki/2010_Asian_Beach_Games "2010 Asian Beach Games").

Oman also hosts tennis tournaments in different age divisions each year. The
[Sultan Qaboos Sports Complex](/wiki/Sultan_Qaboos_Sports_Complex "Sultan
Qaboos Sports Complex") stadium contains a 50-meter swimming pool which is
used for international tournaments from different schools in different
countries. The Tour of Oman, a professional [cycling](/wiki/Cycling "Cycling")
6-day stage race, takes place in February. Oman hosted the Asian [2011 FIFA
Beach Soccer World Cup
qualifiers](/wiki/2011_FIFA_Beach_Soccer_World_Cup_qualification_\(AFC\) "2011
FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup qualification \(AFC\)"), where 11 teams competed
for three spots at the [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Beach_Soccer_World_Cup
"FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup"). Oman hosted the Men's and Women's [2012 Beach
Handball World Championships](/wiki/2012_Beach_Handball_World_Championships
"2012 Beach Handball World Championships") at the Millennium Resort in
Mussanah, from 8 to 13 July.[146] Oman has competed repeatedly for a position
in the [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup"), but have yet
qualified to compete in the tournament.

Oman, along with [Fujairah](/wiki/Fujairah "Fujairah") in the [UAE](/wiki/UAE
"UAE"), are the only regions in the [Middle East](/wiki/Middle_East "Middle
East") that have a variant of [bullfighting](/wiki/Bullfighting
"Bullfighting"), known as 'bull-butting', organized within their
territories.[147] Al-Batena area in Oman is specifically prominent for such
events. It involves two bulls of the [Brahman](/wiki/Brahman_\(cattle\)
"Brahman \(cattle\)") breed pitted against one another and as the name
implies, they engage in a forceful barrage of headbutts. The first one to
collapse or concede its ground is declared the loser. Most bull-butting
matches are short affairs and last for less than 5 minutes.[147][148] The
origins of bull-butting in Oman remain unknown, but many locals believe it was
brought to Oman by the Moors of Spanish origin. Yet others say it has a direct
connection with [Portugal](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal"), which colonized the
Omani coastline for nearly two centuries.[149]

In Cricket, Oman qualified for the [2016 ICC World
Twenty20](/wiki/2016_ICC_World_Twenty20 "2016 ICC World Twenty20") by securing
sixth place in [2015 ICC World Twenty20
Qualifier](/wiki/2015_ICC_World_Twenty20_Qualifier "2015 ICC World Twenty20
Qualifier"). They have also been granted T20I status as they were among the
top six teams in the qualifiers.

## Education

Main article: [Education in Oman](/wiki/Education_in_Oman "Education in Oman")

The adult literacy rate in 2010 was 86.9%.[150] Before 1970, only three formal
schools existed in the entire country, with fewer than 1,000 students. Since
Sultan Qaboos' ascension to power in 1970, the government has given high
priority to education in order to develop a domestic work force, which the
government considers a vital factor in the country's economic and social
progress. Today, there are over 1,000 state schools and about 650,000
students.

Oman's first university, [Sultan Qaboos
University](/wiki/Sultan_Qaboos_University "Sultan Qaboos University"), opened
in 1986. The [University of Nizwa](/wiki/University_of_Nizwa "University of
Nizwa") is one of the fastest growing universities in Oman. Other post-
secondary institutions in Oman include the [Higher College of
Technology](/wiki/Higher_College_of_Technology "Higher College of Technology")
and its six branches, six colleges of applied sciences (including a teacher's
training college), a college of banking and financial studies, an institute of
Sharia sciences, and several nursing institutes. Some 200 scholarships are
awarded each year for study abroad.

According to the [Webometrics Ranking of World
Universities](/wiki/Webometrics_Ranking_of_World_Universities "Webometrics
Ranking of World Universities"), the top-ranking universities in the country
are [Sultan Qaboos University](/wiki/Sultan_Qaboos_University "Sultan Qaboos
University") (1678th worldwide), the Dhofar University (6011th) and the
[University of Nizwa](/wiki/University_of_Nizwa "University of Nizwa")
(6093rd).[151]

## Health

Main article: [Healthcare in Oman](/wiki/Healthcare_in_Oman "Healthcare in
Oman")

Life expectancy at birth in Oman was estimated to be 76.1 years in 2010.[117]
As of 2010[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Oman&action=edit),
there were an estimated 2.1 physicians and 2.1 hospital beds per 1,000
people.[117] In 1993, 89% of the population had access to health care
services. In 2000, 99% of the population had access to health care
services.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] During the last three decades, the Oman health
care system has demonstrated and reported great achievements in health care
services and preventive and curative medicine. In 2001, Oman's health system
was ranked number 8 by the World Health Organization.[152]
